Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: 6th Biennial Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum; Brunswick, ME; June 2020
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support the sixth biannual Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum, which will be held June 15-19, 2020 at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine. The forum will bring together specialists in structural geology and tectonics for oral and poster presentations, field trips, and short courses. The Structural Geology and Tectonics Program provides the framework for the structural geology and tectonics community to communicate, develop, and advance teaching and research among educators and investigators. These forums play a key role in identifying key pedagogical advances and methods applied to structural geology and tectonics, important science questions in structural geology and tectonics, while initiating collaborative relationships to address these questions. The meeting will include three days of presentations that will include technical sessions that involve themes that have been identified by a recently published community vision document that highlighted important research areas in tectonics. The workshop will also identify and discuss pedagogical advances and advances and methods, specifically as they apply to some of the discipline specific challenges of teaching structural geology and tectonics and discuss future directions in tectonics research. It will create opportunities to foster new collaborations through the cross-pollination of ideas and techniques, and it will provide a platform for early career professionals and students that supports and promotes their careers at a critical stage in their professional development. Following the format of previous meetings, each session will highlight an important area of current research and/or education that will be anchored by a distinguished keynote speaker and will showcase relevance of work on the topic. Poster sessions with abundant time for full participant interaction will accompany each session. The forum will be organized to maximize the exchange of ideas between participants in open discussions. Sessions will provide ample opportunity to ask questions of individual presenters, assess the current state of our knowledge, and consider productive areas for future research. In addition to the formal meeting, there will be field trips to examine the geology of selected areas of adjacent areas that will focus on best practices for teaching in the field and leading more accessible field trips. <br/><br/>The Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum is designed to facilitate community building and personal interaction within different segments of the structural geology community. It will bring together faculty from research universities, liberal arts colleges, community and two-year colleges, and minority-serving institutions. Speakers who identify as members of traditionally underrepresented groups as well as professionals from two- and four- year colleges will provide diverse representation across all of the organizing committees for the 2020 forum. Importantly, there will be group discussions on critical developments in structural geology and tectonics, and what future research priorities should be. This community building effort will help create a stronger, more vibrant group of scientists and help introduce graduate students and advanced undergraduates to the structural geology and tectonics disciplines. The setting will be particularly useful for graduate students, who will be able to use the venue and informal nature of the forum to find out what research is taking place at other institutions, meet a wide range of faculty, and develop useful contacts which will be of great value to their future careers. Informal mentoring sessions will facilitate opportunities for early career professionals and students in navigating careers in structural geology and tectonics. Students will present their own work in a friendly environment where they can obtain thoughtful and useful feedback, as well as providing opportunity to build new scientific collaborations. An important contribution of this forum will include a session aimed identifying one session will be aimed at best practices to promote equity, diversity and inclusion in the classroom. By focusing on classroom activities and approaches, successful strategies can be identified that can be adopted by other institutions to minimize the “leaky pipeline” that is known to be part of the problem with retention of underrepresented groups in the geosciences. Abstracts, field guides, and short course notes will be disseminated through a dedicated website that will be publicly accessible. Continued support for the Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum contributes to the long-term health, vitality, and infrastructure of the Earth Science community. The Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum benefits society and advances desired societal outcomes by its emphasis on STEM (science, technology, engineering and math) education and educator development at a variety of levels, by contributing to the training of the next generation of scientists, by contributing to the broadening of underrepresented groups in STEM, and by contributing to the advancement of scientific literacy of the public. These activities contribute to the increased economic and scientific competitiveness of the United States.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 6th Biennial Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum was held at Bowdoin College June 20 - 25, 2022. Originally scheduled to occur in June of 2020, this conference was delayed by two years because of travel and gathering restrictions imposed by the COVID-19 global pandemic. The 53 registered participants included faculty members (at all career stages), postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students.

The main objective of the Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum was to provide an informal and interactive venue for discussing important frontiers, new ideas, and current research in structural geology and tectonics. The Forum also provided opportunities to discuss strategies for effective and inclusive teaching of structural geology and tectonics, including integrating research with teaching.

The Forum consisted of five half-day plenary sessions (held over three days), an afternoon field trip for all conference participants, and two days of optional field trips and workshops that were offered on the days prior to and after the plenary sessions. Each half-day plenary session was devoted to a theme, and invited speakers kicked off each session with engaging talks and extended question and answer sessions. Additional talks (short format and "lighting" talks) and poster presentations rounded out each session. The plenary sessions of the Forum were built around broad themes outlined as important to the community during brainstorming sessions at the annual Geological Society of America Meetings in fall 2020 and 2021 and from abstracts solicited from participants. Session themes included: (1) characterizing and quantifying fault zones from top to bottom; (2) the strength of Earth's tectonic plates - what controls strength and how does strength evolve in time and space; (3) innovations in inclusive teaching practices in structural geology and tectonics; (4) inclusion, accessibility, diversity and equity in structural geology and tectonics; and (5) advances in geology, geochronology, and geophysics. Invited speakers were largely early career researchers and scientists from groups historically marginalized in the geosciences, which helped the Forum meet its goals of broadening participation and providing platforms for the next generation of geoscientists. Each session featured topics deemed as "cutting edge science" at the forefront of our discipline, themes that are critical to advancing our field, and topics essential for broadening participation. One afternoon was dedicated to an all-conference field trip to coastal rock exposures in Harpswell, Maine where we discussed deformation features that range in scale from centimeters to kilometers, teaching practices (including the use of drones and virtual field trips for those with physical disabilities), and new approaches to determining the timing of deformation. Evening sessions included a welcome dinner for participants to catch up and reconnect; a workshop on navigating early career in the geosciences; and a workshop on using a new software platform to collect data in the field that can be easily uploaded into relevant, publicly accessible databases.

Three optional field trips and workshops were held prior to the conference. The topics were: (1) an exploration, observation, and discussion of granites in western Maine; (2) fault zone rocks and processes at three coastal locations in southern and mid-coast Maine; and (3) applications of newly released software (geologic map data extractor - GMDE) in both research and classroom settings. The conference culminated in an optional day-long field trip to four locations in coastal Maine to explore the sequence of rock types and deformation features associated with the Appalachian Mountains.

All sessions were well attended and sparked vibrant conversations and discussions that led to new collaborations among conference participants (which supports the aims of advancing knowledge and improving the infrastructure for research); the discussion and adoption of innovative teaching practices; and celebrations of the career contributions to the structural geology and tectonics community. Funding from the National Science Foundation was used to support participants by offsetting the costs of dining and accommodation during the conference, transportation to and from the conference, and field vehicles during the conference (including bus transportation for all participants to the rocky coast of Maine to explore the themes discussed during the conference). This support broadened participation and provided opportunities for graduate students and professionals to attend and fully participate. Coffee breaks, the cost of printing posters, logistical/technical on-site support for the conference, and modest stipends for keynote speakers and field trip leaders were also supported by the grant. Abstracts, field trip guides, and the entire Forum program is hosted online at https://serc.carleton.edu/NAGTWorkshops/structure/2022_Forum/index.html; funding to support this website was also provided by the grant.
